VOL. XX, NO. 7.

ST. JOHN'S CONTEST SHOWS UP
TEAM'S ABILITY TO COME BACK
Black and Blue Turns Defeat Into Victory in Saturdny's Game—St. John's
Puts Up Great Fight—Every
Man's Support Needed for
M. A.C. Contest.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1915.

BLACK AND BLUE STEAM ROLLER
RIDES TO VICTORY OVER ST. JOHN'S
Hoffman, Brooks, Uhler and Branham Tear Through Orange and
Black Line for Sweeping Victory, 20 to 6—Hopkins
Stages Splendid Come-Back in Last Half.

BY COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

Hopkins accomplished one of its
greatest objects of the season Saturday in defeating St. John's. The
game was a disappointing one in
many ways from the standpoint of
the coaches, but Hopkins won the
game—and much is forgiven when
a team wins a big game.
Our team started with a rush and
scored a touchdown with ease by
straight football, even in the face
of a stiff wind. Then came the
most decided slump and general letdown that Hopkins has experienced
this season. In my opinion, it was
an unconscious easing up due to
over-confidence. That first touchdown, instead of serving as an incentive to the Hopkins team, tended
to make them over-confident and
caieless. They paid dearly • for this
over-confidence, however, for St.
John's started a running attack
Which was not to stop until new
defensive tactics on the part of
Hopkins in the beginning of the
second half checked the steady advances of the Cadets.
In that weird first half, St. John's,
once it found it could gain consistently around Hopkins' ends, became a new team and played better than it really knew how. Hopkins, on the other hand, instead of
bracing and rising to meet the increased strength of St. John's,
seemed to be bewildered and could
not adjust its defense to meet the
simple end run formation of its
oPponents. I am not trying to detract one iota of credit from St.
John's, for their interference on this
Play was very good, but Hopkins
should have adjusted its defense to
meet this style of attack. After it
was fully explained between the
halves, the team was able to stop
the play during the remainder of
the game without much trouble.
The most pleasing feature of the
game was that the Hopkins team
Proved that it could come back and
wrest a Victory from defeat, for in
Spite of the fact that Hopkins was
ahead by one point at the end of
the first half, she had been outplayed by St. John's, and, without
a great reversal of form, would
have been a defeated team. But
the determined spirit of victory was
in that Hopkins team, and it had
the necessary nerve and courage to
come through with the game.
The St. John's team deserves
great credit for the splendid fight
(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

The Hopkins steam roller advanced steadily to victory Saturday,
and although its way was hampered by many obstacles it flattened all
out, and by sheer power won out, 20 to 6.
The game was marked by the power of Hopkins' attack on the line,
and the weakness of the ends in breaking up an ordinary end run formation. On the offensive, Hoffman and Uhler were able at nearly all
stages of the game to tear through the line for heavy gains; and on
the defensive, Branham and Primrose were everywhere, tackling clean
and hard. Branham was responsible for the breaking up of many end
runs which should have been stopped at the wing positions; and Primrose stepped into the limelight, after a let-up of three weeks, showing
old-time form in all points of the game.
The Black and Blue was outplayed in the first half, after it had
made its first touchdown, but staged a great come-back in the latter
part of the game, clearly showing its superiority over the St. John's
machine. Credit must be given the Soldiers for their excellent fight.
What was lacking in the end positions was made up at guard, tackle
and center. Wilkinson, Leibensperger, Barclay and Ormond played excellent football, and with the exception of the poor defense against end runs
and the partial. lack of a good interference, the team worked as a
machine of its .type should.
The game, play by play, was as follows:
Wilkinson opened the game by
kicking off to Hartsock, who carried the - ball to the 30-yard line.
On the next play, Alexander gained
ten• yards for St. John's on a long
end run. Turner attempted another end run, but was set back two
yards. Alexander punted; the wind
made the kick a poor one, and the
ball bounded several times before
Bowers captured it.
Hopkins was now on the offensive and had no difficulty in approaching St. John's goal line. On
the first play, Hoffman made twenty
yards on an end run. Brooks added
seven more. Hopkins gradually
plowed her way through St. John's
territory. After substantial gains
by Brooks, Hoffman and Bowers,
Hoffman put the ball on the i5yard line by a five-yard plunge
through right tackle. St. John's
was penalized on the next play for
holding. With the pigskin on the
Cadets' 5 - yard line, Hoffman
plowed through right tackle for the
first touchdown. Wilkinson kicked
goal. Score: Hopkins, 7; St.
John's, o.
Wilkinson kicked off to Stromeyer, who advanced from the 15yard line until he was spilled by
Bowers on the 35-yard line. Alexander then circled left end for thirty yards, Bowers throwing him with
a fine tackle. St. John's now tried
a number of end runs and a double
pass, but the plays did not materially advance the ball. On a fake
kick, Alexander led a twelve-yard
gain around Hopkins' right end.
The Soldiers were penalized five

yards for off-side play. The ball
was now being rapidly advanced
into Hopkins' territory. Alexander
made a nine-yard gain around left
end and eleven more through right
tackle. On the next play, Turner
plowed through Hopkins' line for a
touchdown. Heise failed to kick
the goal.
Gorman was sent in to replace
Pinney at right end.
St. John's kicked off to Bowers,
who advanced to the 25-yard line.
Hopkins could not break through
the St. John's defense and, after
a short gain by Hoffman, the Black
and Blue was forced to punt. The
whistle blew and the first quarter
ended with the score 7 to 6 in favor
of Hopkins.
Finney replaced Gorman. St.
John's started off on a long end
run, but was penalized fifteen yards
for holding. With the ball on the
Cadets' 3-yard line, Stromeyer made
a sensational ten-yard run around
right end. Alexander also circled
Hopkins' ends for substantial gains.
Yewell took Schmidt's place at
left guard. Stromeyer again made
a ten-yard end run and was downed
by Brooks. Sachs' replaced Finney, who had twisted his knee.
Wilkinson spilled Stromeyer's next
attempt at an end run. On the next
play, the Soldiers were penalized
fifteen yards for holding. Alexander then kicked to Bowers, who
was downed by Dryden on Hopkins' 3o-yard line..
The Black and Blue tried to advance the ball through St. John's.
(Continued on page 4, col. 3)

STEAM ROLLER, GOAT, BAND
AND DUMMY FEATURE PARADE
Procession of Rooters, Bedecked With
Flags and Banners and Armed With
Noise Producers, Creates Big
Sensation on March to
Homewood.

With flags flying, band playing,
sirens and klaxons shrieking and
a very capable-looking steam roller
puffing at its head, the parade of
students formed on Saturday afternoon at i o'clock at McCoy Hall,
and, after a slight delay, prbceeded to Homewood via the usual
Charles street route.
Altogether, the procession was a
most interesting, if not imposing,
spectacle. Headed by a full band,
the steam roller, behind which
dragged a dummy dressed in a
St. John's football suit, and a goat
decorated. with orange and black
drapery, all undergraduates who
could possibly be on hand were .in
line, marching to the field of victory
with the assurance of true conquerors. Although several stops
were made in order to give the
steam roller a chance to catch its
breath, plans worked out exceedingly well and the impression created by the display was undoubtedly
as deep as that of any parade of
years gone by.
Upon its arrival at Homewood,
the procession, now minus the
_roller, entered the west gate of the
athletic field and proceeded past the
St. John's stands to the section reserved for Hopkins rooters. As
the leaders, trailing the dummy,
which was by this time well worn
and bedraggled, passed the St.
John's rooters, the noise of the
various instruments of ear torture
was deafening. The rooters once
seated in the stand, the goat relegated to a safe position and fed
with a sumptuous repast of newspapers and rags, and the band, reenforced by an orchestra of klaxons, sirens and watchmen's rattles
in position, the battle of the rival
stands was on.
Cheering started with a hearty
vigor and continued through the
game, re-enforced by as much artificial noise as could be produced
by the klaxon artillery. During
the intermission the dummy was
hoisted on the end of a rope to a
branch of the old pine tree, from
which position it shed copious tears
of sawdust over the none too sympathetic members of the band.
The sound of the referee's final
whistle had hardly died down when
the occupants of the rooters' stand
swarmed over the fence, and, forming a monster "H" on the field of
battle, celebrated with a final demonstration of joy the success of the
Black and Blue steam roller.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 22, 1915.

DEFINITE POLICY NECESSARY

HOPKINS HEAD HONORED

Norman Angell Points Out that Lack of
Policy Was Cause of European War.
Militarism May Follow the
Present Conflict.

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow Elected One of
the National Municipal League
Vice-Presidents.

Norman Angell, author of "The
Great Illusion," and Atherton
Brownell were the speakers last
Wednesday evening in McCoy Hall
at the meeting of the Maryland
Peace Society. "Diplomatic and
Economic Causes Underlying the
War" was the subject of Mr.
Angell's address, but he devoted
his time almost entirely to a discussion of military preparedness.
A number of his statements were
based on his new book, "The
World Highway," soon to be published.
America, he said, is not removed
from the rest of the world; events
in Europe play their part here.
This war, for instance, has involved the United States in a dispute to vindicate the rights of her
citizens on the seas; it has largely
transformed us from a debtor to a
creditor nation. It may change
American society into a "hyphenization," whereby national groups
will be formed as in Switzerland
and Austria.
Preparedness, perhaps militarism,
Mr. Angell thought, would be one
of the outcomes of the war. "I
have not one word to say against
preparedness in this country," he
said, "but this alone will not be
enough. There must be a preparedness of policy. It was because Europe had no policy that she could
not maintain peace, and if you do
not tell Europe what your intentions are, what your policy is, you
will find yourself in a war. If you.
state what your behavior is to be
on this hemisphere and in the
world at large, then I say the greater your armament the greater the
good to the rest of the world. If
not, however great your military
power, you are not going to defend
your rights."
He pointed out that there were
two forms of neutrality, either one
of which this country might have
chosen. We could either furnish
arms and money to any combatant
who could obtain them, or we could
refuse to supply them at all. The
United States adopted the former
policy. And in so doing we made,
in fact, a form of economic alliance
with the Allies, chiefly because they
were favored by the majority of the
American people. But had we had
an international policy, we would
have shown the nations that not
control of the sea, but international

this way a country could, and
should, throw its economic influence
towards equity among the nations.

latest drama, "The Unseen Empire." This was written before the

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, president
of Johns Hopkins University and
chairman of the Economy and Efficiency Commission, called on Mayor
Preston at the City Hall and for
nearly an hour discussed informally
the city's budget system of making
appropriations. When he left he
expressed satisfaction at the information with which the Mayor supplied him.
The university president was
shown the various forms used by
the municipal departments in making up their annual departmental
estimates. These forms were prepared by Deputy Comptroller William T. Childs and are regarded
by experts as the best and yet the
simplest means of formulating a
budget system.—News.

Following are some of the replies received by the University of
the State of New York in examinations for regents' certificates.
Among those who wrote the replies were candidates for teachers'
positions, for qualification as law
and medical students and for admission to colleges:
The chamois is valuable for its
feathers, the whale for its kerosene
oil.
The feminine gender of friar is
toastress.
There were no Christians among.
the early Gauls. They were mostly lawyers.
Climate is caused by the emotion
of the earth around the sun.
Geometry teaches us how to bisect angles.
The purpose of the skeleton—
something to hitch meat to.
The skeleton is what is left after
the insides have been taken out and
the outsides have been taken off.
A blizzard is the inside of a hen.
A vacuum is a large empty space
where the Pope lives.
A circle is a round straight line
with a hole in the middle.
When Cicero delivered his oration he was a prefix.
George Washington married
Martha Curtis and in due time became the father of his country.
Sixty gallons make one hedgehog.
The stomach is just south of the
ribs.
The alimentary canal is located
in the northern part of Indiana.
The rosetta stone was a missionary to Turkey.
The government of England is a
limited mockery.
Georgia was founded by people
who had been executed.
A mountain pass is a pass given
by the railroad to its employes so
that they can spend their vacation
in the mountains.
A mountain range is a large cook
stove.
The qualifications of a voter at
a school meeting are that he must
be the father of a child for eight
weeks.
Achilles was dipped in the River
Styx to make him immoral.
Gender shows whether man is
feminine, masculine or neuter.
Gravitation is that if there were

The function of the stomach is
to hold up the petticoats.
The stomach forms a part of the
Adams Apple.

When the British got up in the
morning and saw the Americans

Pompeii was destroyed by an
eruption of saliva from the Vatican.
Weapons of the Indian—bow, arrow, tomahawk and warhoop.
Typhoid fever is prevented by
fascination.—Star.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 22, 1915.
Good Sportsmen.

In going over the events of Saturday afternoon, one can hardly fail
to bear in mind'the extremely good
grace with which the St. John's
Cadets took their defeat. The Soldiers came up to Baltimore' with
the idea in mind that they were
going to carry home a victory and
they sat through a game in which
they saw the laurels for which
they were working gradually being
wrested from them. After the
game, the sportsmanlike attitude
which they clearly manifested impressed all who tarried to watch
the final demonstrations by the students. It must be said that what
they did was not an easy thing to
do, and the fact that they did it with
such evident sincerity reflects high
credit upon them.
The Steam Roller.

The steam roller is the emblem
of irresistible force. Before it,
nothing can stand; after it, there
conies the victorious march of the
conquerors. The steam roller was
the token of the first great army
that swept into Austria; the steam
roller was the symbol of Wilhelm
himself for the advance of the Germans; the steam roller was the
proud battle cry of the "royal
family" of very Baltimore in the
balmiest days of undivided allegiance. The steam roller means victory—relentless, on-sweeping victory—the triumph of the machine.
The triumph of the machine,
brains and bodies adjusted to instinctive unity—we have seen it,and,
by its own token, we have heralded
it! The team, the coaches and the
rooters—the Hopkins steam roller—
it has gone on and on, one rival
after the other has been crushed beneath its invincible onslaught, its

steel is bloody with its latest triumph. There remains but one obstruction in its path—one mighty
barrier between it and its goal.
There is a groaning of joints, a
creaking of hinges, a pulsing of engines. It moves steadily, irresistibly; it is advancing on to the last
obstacle that stands before it, and
its victory is sure, for it is the
steam roller—the Hopkins steam
roller—and it is indomitable.
Next!

Now that the St. John's game is
over and our rivals have been satisfactorily humbled, the time has
come for the consideration of what
is undoubtedly, from every point
of view, the most important game
of the season — the Thanksgiving
Day contest with the Maryland
Agricultural College.
Not only does the game with the
Aggies come at the close of the
season, but it comes also as a very
real climax on the Hopkins schedule. Always represented by a
strong and aggressive team, the Agricultural College has this year developed one of the most powerful
organizations in its history, and this
combination is standing as the one
significant barrier in the way of the
realization of Hopkins' long-desired
championship of the State.
A consideration of comparative
scores gives little or no indication
as to the outcome of Thursday's
contest, but it justifies the confidence felt by each institution in the
team which will represent it. Both
large scores and great confidence
have frequently proved to be misleading in the matter of football victories, however, and this has been
particularly the case during the
present season. The savage determination that led Yale to triumph
over Princeton is of more value
than a remembrance of past triumphs, or a rosy faith in the future.
The Maryland Aggies cannot beat
a Johns Hopkins that is willing to
go the limit, to fight savagely and to
the end.
Though every member of the
team be bruised and limping,
though not a Hopkins man be able
to speak above a whisper in the
week following the Aggie game, it
will be a memorable week of very
real triumph if the new Hopkins
spirit has made itself felt in the
State, and Brickley's team has won
the Maryland championship. Football victories are not empty triumphs—they have a moral effect on
the entire student body that is both
significant and lasting. Johns Hopkins really needs a victory in the
Aggie game. It would mean that,
given a good start toward a successful season, the punch was present that is required to make accomplished facts of potentialities. Johns
Hopkins will win the game if every
Hopkins man really and sincerely
wants it to, and is ready to do his
utmost in the way of assistance.
The chance is ours—are we big
enough to take it? Who will win
the Aggie game Thanksgiving
Day?

Chess Club Elects Officers.

The Chess Club held a meeting
last week to organize for this year.
Melamet, '16, was elected president
of the club, and Taylor, '18, was
chosen as secretary. There were
only nine present at the meeting,
eight of these being men who have
been on the Chess Club before.
Since there must be a larger number of candidates, everyone who
knows anything at all about playing chess is strongly urged to be
present at the next meeting of the
club. This will be held on Monday,
November 29, at one o'clock.
After the club gets well under
way a tournament is going to be
held among the members, and, if
enough men come out for the club,
some matches will undoubtedly be
arranged with the chess clubs from
other colleges.
Brickley to Coach Freshman Team.

The Freshman Class held its regular bi-weekly meeting on Thursday, November 18, at i P. M.
President Ronald A. Cox presided
over the meeting, which was unusually well attended.
Chairman Schmidt, of the Athletic Committee, announced that
Mr. Brickley had consented to
coach the freshman football team
during the week before the game
with the sophomores, which comes
off on December 4.
Caspari was appointed cheer
leader for the class, and he in turn
appointed Thomsen and Fields as
his assistants.
A committee consisting of Lenhard, McCormick, Frisch, Eby,
Fields and Thomsen was appointed
to see about getting a class banner
before the sophomore game.

Harvard University no longer allows tradesmen, book-agents, laundry men, or solicitors of any kind to
seek business with the students.
This ban is effective throughout the
college year. Only such tradesmen
as are especially summoned by the
students can enter the• university
grounds, and then they must leave
as soon as their business is transacted.

Hardy Elected to Cotillon Board.

At a meeting of the non-fraternity
men held last Thursday, Mr. Arthur A. Hardy was elected the nonfraternity member of this year's
Cotillon Board. The meeting was
called to order by Mr. T. J. Tingley, president of the Senior Class,
and was adjourned immediately
after the election.
The custom of having a man not
affiliated with any of the fraternities as a member of the Cotillon
Board is of comparatively recent
date, and was introduced after a
discussion of the matter in the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER.

it put up. The Cadets were not
in the best of shape, but they made
no excuses and played their hardest to win. I have nothing but
praise for Coach Wilson, Captain
Heise and the St. John's players.
And now for the last game of the
year on Thanksgiving Day with
Maryland Agricultural College.
This game should be close and desperately fought for on both sides.
Hopkins will be at a disadvantage
in playing another big game with
only three days' rest, while Maryland Agricultural College has had
ten days' rest; but we are offering
no excuses. I feel sure that Hopkins will be at its best on Thursday. Every man on the team realizes the task before him. Every
man knows that if we are to win
it will take the very best that he
can give, and I feel confident that
every man on Hopkins will give all
he has for the University on next
Thursday.
At the mass-meeting on Wednesday we are planning to have the
whole squad on the platform, so
that the undergraduates may have
a chance to see at close range the
men who have labored and sacrificed their time for the honor of
Hopkins in football. Let every
Hopkins man be there, and show
the team that the whole University
is behind it. On Wednesday afternoon at 4.30 o'clock let every Hopkins man — undergraduates and
those of the alumni who can get
away, from business—be out to
Homewood to cheer the team at its
last practice. The team will do its
part on Thursday, but it needs the
hearty and unqualified support of
every Hopkins man. We can win,
we must win and we will win, but
the team must have the undivided
support of every Hopkins man to
come out victorious.

VOL. XX, NO. 7.

ST. JOHN'S CONTEST SHOWS UP
TEAM'S ABILITY TO COME BACK
Black and Blue Turns Defeat Into Victory in Saturdny's Game—St. John's
Puts Up Great Fight—Every
Man's Support Needed for
M. A.C. Contest.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1915.

BLACK AND BLUE STEAM ROLLER
RIDES TO VICTORY OVER ST. JOHN'S
Hoffman, Brooks, Uhler and Branham Tear Through Orange and
Black Line for Sweeping Victory, 20 to 6—Hopkins
Stages Splendid Come-Back in Last Half.

BY COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

Hopkins accomplished one of its
greatest objects of the season Saturday in defeating St. John's. The
game was a disappointing one in
many ways from the standpoint of
the coaches, but Hopkins won the
game—and much is forgiven when
a team wins a big game.
Our team started with a rush and
scored a touchdown with ease by
straight football, even in the face
of a stiff wind. Then came the
most decided slump and general letdown that Hopkins has experienced
this season. In my opinion, it was
an unconscious easing up due to
over-confidence. That first touchdown, instead of serving as an incentive to the Hopkins team, tended
to make them over-confident and
caieless. They paid dearly • for this
over-confidence, however, for St.
John's started a running attack
Which was not to stop until new
defensive tactics on the part of
Hopkins in the beginning of the
second half checked the steady advances of the Cadets.
In that weird first half, St. John's,
once it found it could gain consistently around Hopkins' ends, became a new team and played better than it really knew how. Hopkins, on the other hand, instead of
bracing and rising to meet the increased strength of St. John's,
seemed to be bewildered and could
not adjust its defense to meet the
simple end run formation of its
oPponents. I am not trying to detract one iota of credit from St.
John's, for their interference on this
Play was very good, but Hopkins
should have adjusted its defense to
meet this style of attack. After it
was fully explained between the
halves, the team was able to stop
the play during the remainder of
the game without much trouble.
The most pleasing feature of the
game was that the Hopkins team
Proved that it could come back and
wrest a Victory from defeat, for in
Spite of the fact that Hopkins was
ahead by one point at the end of
the first half, she had been outplayed by St. John's, and, without
a great reversal of form, would
have been a defeated team. But
the determined spirit of victory was
in that Hopkins team, and it had
the necessary nerve and courage to
come through with the game.
The St. John's team deserves
great credit for the splendid fight
(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

The Hopkins steam roller advanced steadily to victory Saturday,
and although its way was hampered by many obstacles it flattened all
out, and by sheer power won out, 20 to 6.
The game was marked by the power of Hopkins' attack on the line,
and the weakness of the ends in breaking up an ordinary end run formation. On the offensive, Hoffman and Uhler were able at nearly all
stages of the game to tear through the line for heavy gains; and on
the defensive, Branham and Primrose were everywhere, tackling clean
and hard. Branham was responsible for the breaking up of many end
runs which should have been stopped at the wing positions; and Primrose stepped into the limelight, after a let-up of three weeks, showing
old-time form in all points of the game.
The Black and Blue was outplayed in the first half, after it had
made its first touchdown, but staged a great come-back in the latter
part of the game, clearly showing its superiority over the St. John's
machine. Credit must be given the Soldiers for their excellent fight.
What was lacking in the end positions was made up at guard, tackle
and center. Wilkinson, Leibensperger, Barclay and Ormond played excellent football, and with the exception of the poor defense against end runs
and the partial. lack of a good interference, the team worked as a
machine of its .type should.
The game, play by play, was as follows:
Wilkinson opened the game by
kicking off to Hartsock, who carried the - ball to the 30-yard line.
On the next play, Alexander gained
ten• yards for St. John's on a long
end run. Turner attempted another end run, but was set back two
yards. Alexander punted; the wind
made the kick a poor one, and the
ball bounded several times before
Bowers captured it.
Hopkins was now on the offensive and had no difficulty in approaching St. John's goal line. On
the first play, Hoffman made twenty
yards on an end run. Brooks added
seven more. Hopkins gradually
plowed her way through St. John's
territory. After substantial gains
by Brooks, Hoffman and Bowers,
Hoffman put the ball on the i5yard line by a five-yard plunge
through right tackle. St. John's
was penalized on the next play for
holding. With the pigskin on the
Cadets' 5 - yard line, Hoffman
plowed through right tackle for the
first touchdown. Wilkinson kicked
goal. Score: Hopkins, 7; St.
John's, o.
Wilkinson kicked off to Stromeyer, who advanced from the 15yard line until he was spilled by
Bowers on the 35-yard line. Alexander then circled left end for thirty yards, Bowers throwing him with
a fine tackle. St. John's now tried
a number of end runs and a double
pass, but the plays did not materially advance the ball. On a fake
kick, Alexander led a twelve-yard
gain around Hopkins' right end.
The Soldiers were penalized five

yards for off-side play. The ball
was now being rapidly advanced
into Hopkins' territory. Alexander
made a nine-yard gain around left
end and eleven more through right
tackle. On the next play, Turner
plowed through Hopkins' line for a
touchdown. Heise failed to kick
the goal.
Gorman was sent in to replace
Pinney at right end.
St. John's kicked off to Bowers,
who advanced to the 25-yard line.
Hopkins could not break through
the St. John's defense and, after
a short gain by Hoffman, the Black
and Blue was forced to punt. The
whistle blew and the first quarter
ended with the score 7 to 6 in favor
of Hopkins.
Finney replaced Gorman. St.
John's started off on a long end
run, but was penalized fifteen yards
for holding. With the ball on the
Cadets' 3-yard line, Stromeyer made
a sensational ten-yard run around
right end. Alexander also circled
Hopkins' ends for substantial gains.
Yewell took Schmidt's place at
left guard. Stromeyer again made
a ten-yard end run and was downed
by Brooks. Sachs' replaced Finney, who had twisted his knee.
Wilkinson spilled Stromeyer's next
attempt at an end run. On the next
play, the Soldiers were penalized
fifteen yards for holding. Alexander then kicked to Bowers, who
was downed by Dryden on Hopkins' 3o-yard line..
The Black and Blue tried to advance the ball through St. John's.
(Continued on page 4, col. 3)

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

STEAM ROLLER, GOAT, BAND
AND DUMMY FEATURE PARADE
Procession of Rooters, Bedecked With
Flags and Banners and Armed With
Noise Producers, Creates Big
Sensation on March to
Homewood.

With flags flying, band playing,
sirens and klaxons shrieking and
a very capable-looking steam roller
puffing at its head, the parade of
students formed on Saturday afternoon at i o'clock at McCoy Hall,
and, after a slight delay, prbceeded to Homewood via the usual
Charles street route.
Altogether, the procession was a
most interesting, if not imposing,
spectacle. Headed by a full band,
the steam roller, behind which
dragged a dummy dressed in a
St. John's football suit, and a goat
decorated. with orange and black
drapery, all undergraduates who
could possibly be on hand were .in
line, marching to the field of victory
with the assurance of true conquerors. Although several stops
were made in order to give the
steam roller a chance to catch its
breath, plans worked out exceedingly well and the impression created by the display was undoubtedly
as deep as that of any parade of
years gone by.
Upon its arrival at Homewood,
the procession, now minus the
_roller, entered the west gate of the
athletic field and proceeded past the
St. John's stands to the section reserved for Hopkins rooters. As
the leaders, trailing the dummy,
which was by this time well worn
and bedraggled, passed the St.
John's rooters, the noise of the
various instruments of ear torture
was deafening. The rooters once
seated in the stand, the goat relegated to a safe position and fed
with a sumptuous repast of newspapers and rags, and the band, reenforced by an orchestra of klaxons, sirens and watchmen's rattles
in position, the battle of the rival
stands was on.
Cheering started with a hearty
vigor and continued through the
game, re-enforced by as much artificial noise as could be produced
by the klaxon artillery. During
the intermission the dummy was
hoisted on the end of a rope to a
branch of the old pine tree, from
which position it shed copious tears
of sawdust over the none too sympathetic members of the band.
The sound of the referee's final
whistle had hardly died down when
the occupants of the rooters' stand
swarmed over the fence, and, forming a monster "H" on the field of
battle, celebrated with a final demonstration of joy the success of the
Black and Blue steam roller.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 22, 1915.

DEFINITE POLICY NECESSARY

HOPKINS HEAD HONORED

Norman Angell Points Out that Lack of
Policy Was Cause of European War.
Militarism May Follow the
Present Conflict.

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow Elected One of
the National Municipal League
Vice-Presidents.

Norman Angell, author of "The
Great Illusion," and Atherton
Brownell were the speakers last
Wednesday evening in McCoy Hall
at the meeting of the Maryland
Peace Society. "Diplomatic and
Economic Causes Underlying the
War" was the subject of Mr.
Angell's address, but he devoted
his time almost entirely to a discussion of military preparedness.
A number of his statements were
based on his new book, "The
World Highway," soon to be published.
America, he said, is not removed
from the rest of the world; events
in Europe play their part here.
This war, for instance, has involved the United States in a dispute to vindicate the rights of her
citizens on the seas; it has largely
transformed us from a debtor to a
creditor nation. It may change
American society into a "hyphenization," whereby national groups
will be formed as in Switzerland
and Austria.
Preparedness, perhaps militarism,
Mr. Angell thought, would be one
of the outcomes of the war. "I
have not one word to say against
preparedness in this country," he
said, "but this alone will not be
enough. There must be a preparedness of policy. It was because Europe had no policy that she could
not maintain peace, and if you do
not tell Europe what your intentions are, what your policy is, you
will find yourself in a war. If you.
state what your behavior is to be
on this hemisphere and in the
world at large, then I say the greater your armament the greater the
good to the rest of the world. If
not, however great your military
power, you are not going to defend
your rights."
He pointed out that there were
two forms of neutrality, either one
of which this country might have
chosen. We could either furnish
arms and money to any combatant
who could obtain them, or we could
refuse to supply them at all. The
United States adopted the former
policy. And in so doing we made,
in fact, a form of economic alliance
with the Allies, chiefly because they
were favored by the majority of the
American people. But had we had
an international policy, we would
have shown the nations that not
control of the sea, but international

this way a country could, and
should, throw its economic influence
towards equity among the nations.

latest drama, "The Unseen Empire." This was written before the

Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, president
of Johns Hopkins University and
chairman of the Economy and Efficiency Commission, called on Mayor
Preston at the City Hall and for
nearly an hour discussed informally
the city's budget system of making
appropriations. When he left he
expressed satisfaction at the information with which the Mayor supplied him.
The university president was
shown the various forms used by
the municipal departments in making up their annual departmental
estimates. These forms were prepared by Deputy Comptroller William T. Childs and are regarded
by experts as the best and yet the
simplest means of formulating a
budget system.—News.

of the earth around the sun.

something to hitch meat to.

ribs.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 22, 1915.
Good Sportsmen.

In going over the events of Saturday afternoon, one can hardly fail
to bear in mind'the extremely good
grace with which the St. John's
Cadets took their defeat. The Soldiers came up to Baltimore' with
the idea in mind that they were
going to carry home a victory and
they sat through a game in which
they saw the laurels for which
they were working gradually being
wrested from them. After the
game, the sportsmanlike attitude
which they clearly manifested impressed all who tarried to watch
the final demonstrations by the students. It must be said that what
they did was not an easy thing to
do, and the fact that they did it with
such evident sincerity reflects high
credit upon them.
The Steam Roller.

The steam roller is the emblem
of irresistible force. Before it,
nothing can stand; after it, there
conies the victorious march of the
conquerors. The steam roller was
the token of the first great army
that swept into Austria; the steam
roller was the symbol of Wilhelm
himself for the advance of the Germans; the steam roller was the
proud battle cry of the "royal
family" of very Baltimore in the
balmiest days of undivided allegiance. The steam roller means victory—relentless, on-sweeping victory—the triumph of the machine.
The triumph of the machine,
brains and bodies adjusted to instinctive unity—we have seen it,and,
by its own token, we have heralded
it! The team, the coaches and the
rooters—the Hopkins steam roller—
it has gone on and on, one rival
after the other has been crushed beneath its invincible onslaught, its

steel is bloody with its latest triumph. There remains but one obstruction in its path—one mighty
barrier between it and its goal.
There is a groaning of joints, a
creaking of hinges, a pulsing of engines. It moves steadily, irresistibly; it is advancing on to the last
obstacle that stands before it, and
its victory is sure, for it is the
steam roller—the Hopkins steam
roller—and it is indomitable.
Next!

Now that the St. John's game is
over and our rivals have been satisfactorily humbled, the time has
come for the consideration of what
is undoubtedly, from every point
of view, the most important game
of the season — the Thanksgiving
Day contest with the Maryland
Agricultural College.
Not only does the game with the
Aggies come at the close of the
season, but it comes also as a very
real climax on the Hopkins schedule. Always represented by a
strong and aggressive team, the Agricultural College has this year developed one of the most powerful
organizations in its history, and this
combination is standing as the one
significant barrier in the way of the
realization of Hopkins' long-desired
championship of the State.
A consideration of comparative
scores gives little or no indication
as to the outcome of Thursday's
contest, but it justifies the confidence felt by each institution in the
team which will represent it. Both
large scores and great confidence
have frequently proved to be misleading in the matter of football victories, however, and this has been
particularly the case during the
present season. The savage determination that led Yale to triumph
over Princeton is of more value
than a remembrance of past triumphs, or a rosy faith in the future.
The Maryland Aggies cannot beat
a Johns Hopkins that is willing to
go the limit, to fight savagely and to
the end.
Though every member of the
team be bruised and limping,
though not a Hopkins man be able
to speak above a whisper in the
week following the Aggie game, it
will be a memorable week of very
real triumph if the new Hopkins
spirit has made itself felt in the
State, and Brickley's team has won
the Maryland championship. Football victories are not empty triumphs—they have a moral effect on
the entire student body that is both
significant and lasting. Johns Hopkins really needs a victory in the
Aggie game. It would mean that,
given a good start toward a successful season, the punch was present that is required to make accomplished facts of potentialities. Johns
Hopkins will win the game if every
Hopkins man really and sincerely
wants it to, and is ready to do his
utmost in the way of assistance.
The chance is ours—are we big
enough to take it? Who will win
the Aggie game Thanksgiving
Day?

RIDES TO VICTORY OVER ST. JOHN'S

line. Several attempts made by
Hoffman and Brooks were unsuccessful, and Hopkins was forced to
kick. Alexander, who caught the
ball, advanced to the 25-yard line
and the Orange and Black made
fifteen yards more by the hard line
plunging of Jarman and Stromeyer.
At this point the Soldiers were penalized five yards, but Alexander
made up the loss by advancing the
ball five yards on a long run around
right end. He made another similar attempt on the next play, but
failed. Stromeyer again came into
the limelight by making a sensational plunge through center, netting thirty-eight yards. He put the
pigskin on Hopkins' 18-yard line,
and, on a short end run, brought
the ball to the io-yard line. Uhler
went in, taking Brooks' place.
Stromeyer made three yards
through right tackle, but on the
next play, St. John's fumbled;
Hoffman regained the ball on the
5-yard line, and the Black and Blue
punted out of danger.
After failing in several plays to
advance the ball, St. John's attempted a drop-kick, but the pigskin fell fifteen yards short. Hopkins, now on the offensive, also
failed to gain and was compelled
to punt. Jarman caught the ball
and advanced ten yards. Time for
the first half was called with the
ball on Hopkins' 25-yard line.
Score: Hopkins, 7; St. John's, 6.
In the second half, Primrose took
the place of Ormond. Heise kicked
off. Uhler caught the ball and ran
up to Hopkins' 30-yard line. Hoffman, after going through the line
for three yards, was, on the next
play, pushed back five and was
forced to punt.
The Soldiers lost five yards on
a double pass and on the next play
failed to complete a forward pass.
Alexander kicked, and St. John's
was penalized fifteen yards for interfering with Bowers when he was
trying to catch the ball.
Hoffman went through the line
for twenty yards. Uhler tore off
five more. Hopkins then made the
first successful forward pass of the
game, Hoffman to Leibensperger.
The play netted fifteen yards. The
pigskin was now on St. John's 10yard line. First Hoffman forged
ahead for five yards, then Uhler
added three more. Hoffman carried the ball over on the next play,
and Wilkinson kicked the goal.
Score: Hopkins, 14; St. John's 6.
On the kick-off, Selby, who
caught the ball, was knocked out
by Primrose's hard tackle. Stromeyer made four yards, but then
lost five when Leibensperger put
him back on an attempted long end
run. St. John's punted to Bowers,
who placed the ball on the 30-yard
line. The Soldiers appeared to
weaken. Uhler and Hoffman had
no trouble in alternately plowing
through St. John's line. Branham

and Bowers plunged through center
for considerable gains. The third
quarter ended with the ball on the
25-yard line.
On the first play of the last quarter, Uhler made two yards, and
Hoffman followed with five more.
A Hopkins penalty (fifteen yards
for holding) placed the ball on the
20-yard line. A beautiful forward
pass, Hoffman to Fulton, cleared
sixteen yards, and, with the ball on
the Cadets' 4-yard line, Uhler went
through for a touchdown. Wilkinson failed to kick goal. Score:
Hopkins, 20; St. John's, 6.
There was no further scoring
during the game. Hopkins kicked
off. The ball was downed on St.
John's 25-yard line. The Soldiers
could not advance the ball and
punted. Hopkins now gradually
pushed on. Hoffman, Uhler and
Branham all made substantial gains.
Hoffman tried a long pass to Fulton, but it failed. On the next play,
Hoffman attempted a drop-kick,
which just missed the bar. The
ball was put on St. John's 20-yard
line. They made a first down on
line plunging and then attempted
a forward pass, which was caught
by Hoffman. Hopkins failed to
gain and kicked.
St. John's, on the offensive, tried
long end runs, but they were unable to advance the ball. After an
attempted forward pass, the ball
went to Hopkins on downs. Darley was sent in for Bowers. The
Black and Blue advanced fifteen
yards and then was forced to kick.
St. John's, after trying a number of forward passes (all of which
failed), punted to Darley. Frank
replaced Barclay. Hoffman tore off
ten yards and Uhler added five
more. The ball was now on St.
John's 2o-yard line. A number of
Hopkin's substitutes were sent in—
Duncan for Hoffman, Sonneborn
for Wilkinson and Aubrey for Leibensperger. A slow advance was
made toward the St. John's goal
line, but time was called before the
ball could be taken over. Final
score: Hopkins, 20; St. John's, 6.

Chess Club Elects Officers.

The Chess Club held a meeting
last week to organize for this year.
Melamet, '16, was elected president
of the club, and Taylor, '18, was
chosen as secretary. There were
only nine present at the meeting,
eight of these being men who have
been on the Chess Club before.
Since there must be a larger number of candidates, everyone who
knows anything at all about playing chess is strongly urged to be
present at the next meeting of the
club. This will be held on Monday,
November 29, at one o'clock.
After the club gets well under
way a tournament is going to be
held among the members, and, if
enough men come out for the club,
some matches will undoubtedly be
arranged with the chess clubs from
other colleges.
Brickley to Coach Freshman Team.

The Freshman Class held its regular bi-weekly meeting on Thursday, November 18, at i P. M.
President Ronald A. Cox presided
over the meeting, which was unusually well attended.
Chairman Schmidt, of the Athletic Committee, announced that
Mr. Brickley had consented to
coach the freshman football team
during the week before the game
with the sophomores, which comes
off on December 4.
Caspari was appointed cheer
leader for the class, and he in turn
appointed Thomsen and Fields as
his assistants.
A committee consisting of Lenhard, McCormick, Frisch, Eby,
Fields and Thomsen was appointed
to see about getting a class banner
before the sophomore game.

Harvard University no longer allows tradesmen, book-agents, laundry men, or solicitors of any kind to
seek business with the students.
This ban is effective throughout the
college year. Only such tradesmen
as are especially summoned by the
students can enter the• university
grounds, and then they must leave

Hardy Elected to Cotillon Board.

At a meeting of the non-fraternity
men held last Thursday, Mr. Arthur A. Hardy was elected the nonfraternity member of this year's
Cotillon Board. The meeting was
called to order by Mr. T. J. Tingley, president of the Senior Class,
and was adjourned immediately
after the election.
The custom of having a man not
affiliated with any of the fraternities as a member of the Cotillon
Board is of comparatively recent
date, and was introduced after a
discussion of the matter in the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHN'S CONTEST SHOWS UP
TEAM'S ABILITY TO COME BACK

(('ontinued from page 1)
it put up. The Cadets were not
in the best of shape, but they made
no excuses and played their hardest to win. I have nothing but
praise for Coach Wilson, Captain
Heise and the St. John's players.
And now for the last game of the
year on Thanksgiving Day with
Maryland Agricultural College.
This game should be close and desperately fought for on both sides.
Hopkins will be at a disadvantage
in playing another big game with
only three days' rest, while Maryland Agricultural College has had
ten days' rest; but we are offering
no excuses. I feel sure that Hopkins will be at its best on Thursday. Every man on the team realizes the task before him. Every
man knows that if we are to win
it will take the very best that he
can give, and I feel confident that
every man on Hopkins will give all
he has for the University on next
Thursday.
At the mass-meeting on Wednesday we are planning to have the
whole squad on the platform, so
that the undergraduates may have
a chance to see at close range the
men who have labored and sacrificed their time for the honor of
Hopkins in football. Let every
Hopkins man be there, and show
the team that the whole University
is behind it. On Wednesday afternoon at 4.30 o'clock let every Hopkins man — undergraduates and
those of the alumni who can get
away, from business—be out to
Homewood to cheer the team at its
last practice. The team will do its
part on Thursday, but it needs the
hearty and unqualified support of
every Hopkins man. We can win,
we must win and we will win, but
the team must have the undivided
support of every Hopkins man to
come out victorious.
